items.title: [Bug] Hydra Resolvers Not Being Propagated
items.body:
# 🐛 Bug
## Description

Follow up for #861 I'm using submitit to launch jobs and they can't resolve the `${hyda:...}` interpolations. 

## Checklist
- [x] I checked on the latest version of Hydra
- [x] I created a minimal repro

## To reproduce

** Minimal Code/Config snippet to reproduce **

This **minimal** code makes sure the error message is written to the console used to launch: 

```
import time
import hydra
import submitit

def single_job(cfg) -> None:
    print(cfg.data.stats)


def follow(job):
    with open(job.paths.stdout) as fo:
        with open(job.paths.stderr) as fe:
            while True:
                lo = fo.readline()
                    
                if lo:
                    yield lo   

                le = fe.readline()
                if le:
                    yield le

                if job.state != 'RUNNING' and not (le or lo):
                    break
                else:
                    time.sleep(0.1)


@hydra.main(config_name="../configs/test.yaml")
def main(cfg) -> None:
    executor = submitit.LocalExecutor(folder='output')
    job = executor.submit(single_job, cfg)

    while job.state != "RUNNING":
        time.sleep(1)

    while not job.paths.stdout.exists():
        time.sleep(1)

    loglines = follow(job)
    for line in loglines:
        print(line, end='', flush=True)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

Config:

```
data:
  stats: ${hydra:runtime.cwd}/stats/cstats.pt
```

** Stack trace/error message **
```

    self._format_and_raise(key=key, value=None, cause=e)

items.title: [Feature Request] Use ConfigStore without YAML
items.body:
# 🚀 Feature Request

It should be possible only to use a structured config, and no YAML config. The config gives the defaults and command-line arguments etc are used to override the defaults.

## Motivation

ConfigStore is very useful. To use ConfigStore, you must use structured configs. Structured configs are good, but it is cumbersome for some use-cases to maintain the config both in Python and in YAML. In this case, we would prefer ONLY to use the Python and not maintain a YAML version.

## Pitch

We are currently refactoring a large code base with hyperparams and configs scattered through the code. Putting this both in structured config and YAML is a stumbling block, so we will only use one.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

YAML is optional.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Only use YAML.

**Are you willing to open a pull request?** (See [CONTRIBUTING](../../CONTRIBUTING.md))

Not currently.

## Additional context
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

items.title: Allow calling instantiate on any types
items.body:
hydra.util.instantiate can accept arbitrary config object (namely structured configs) that has a `_target_` string field.
The API should allow passing those in safely even without extending TargetConf.

items.title: [Bug] Hydra's override grammar allows quoted resolver args, but OmegaConf does not recognize them
items.body:
# 🐛 Bug

## Description

Best explained with an example (assume a basic `my_app.py` that prints the resolved config):

```bash
python my_app.py +port='${env:PORT}'     # works, may crash if PORT is not defined
python my_app.py +port='${env:PORT,80}'  # crashes: not recognized by Hydra's grammar
python my_app.py +port='${env:PORT,"80"}'  # accepted by Hydra but OmegaConf does not resolve it
```

This is because in the current version of OmegaConf, quotes are not allowed inside interpolations.

## Checklist
- [x] I checked on the latest version of Hydra
- [x] I created a minimal repro

## To reproduce

** Minimal Code/Config snippet to reproduce **

```python
from omegaconf import DictConfig, OmegaConf
import hydra

@hydra.main()
def my_app(cfg: DictConfig) -> None:
    print(OmegaConf.to_yaml(cfg, resolve=True))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    my_app()
```

Then try the examples above.

** Stack trace/error message **

Just showing the last example:
```
port: ${env:PORT,"80"}
```

## Expected Behavior
Hydra should allow the same characters as OmegaConf.

## System information
- **Hydra Version** :  current master (7afee097)
- **Python version** : 3.8.3
- **Virtual environment type and version** : conda 4.8.3
- **Operating system** : MacOS

items.title: Deprecated ObjectConf for TargetConf
items.body:
This is a partial implementation of #566.

## TLDR
Object configs is changing from:
```yaml
target: classname
params:
  a: 10
  b: 20
```
to:
```yaml
_target_: classname
a: 10
b: 20
```
This include Hydra's launchers and sweepers, so if they appear in your config file you will need to adjust the configs.

## Details

ObjectConf:
```python
@dataclass
class ObjectConf(Dict[str, Any]):
    # class, class method or function name
    target: str = MISSING

    # parameters to pass to cls when calling it
    params: Any = field(default_factory=dict)
```

TargetConf:
```python
@dataclass
class TargetConf:
    """
    Use by subclassing and adding fields
    e.g:
    @dataclass
    class UserConf(TargetConf):
        _target_ = "module.User"
        name: str = MISSING
        age: int = MISSING
    """

    # class, class method or function name
    _target_: str = MISSING
```

This will be deprecated for user code, but for Hydra it's a breaking change because sweeper and launchers will no longer need the pesky params to override their parameters:
```
$ python foo.py hydra.sweeper.params.max_batch_size=2
# will become
$ python foo.py hydra.sweeper.max_batch_size=2
```

items.title: [Bug]: Nevergrad sweeper does not work with integers if there are less than 6 choices
items.body:
Nevergrad sweeper complains if it has less than 6 values to sweep over in a range (e.g. `lower: 1` `upper:3`) and asks to use a list instead (`ValueError: For integers with 6 or fewer values, use a choice instead`). But if you use a list with integers it does not work because it assumes that choices contain only strings:

![Screen Shot 2020-08-15 at 7 42 39 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24327668/90323444-84a3b680-df2f-11ea-8d77-1ce82ab9c7c6.png)

Line where the first error is raised: https://github.com/facebookresearch/hydra/blob/0e001afb2a55275b6f7dc33e79035dbf3a797c00/plugins/hydra_nevergrad_sweeper/hydra_plugins/hydra_nevergrad_sweeper/core.py#L178
Hydra Version: 1.0.0rc2


Of course I can give a string and then convert in my code, but it would probably be better to solve it differently? For example sliently treating it as a list without raising the first error ? Or at least to say in the raised error that you have to use a list and convert the str to int in your own code ? Not sure what is the best way..

items.title: Allow overriding of defaults list and hydra node regardless of node schema
items.body:
Given this primary config node:

```python
@dataclass
class Config(DictConfig):
  name: str = MISSING
  age: int = MISSING

cs = ConfigStore.instance()
cs.store(name="config", node=Config)
```

It does not mention the hydra node or the defaults list.
This means that overriding either from the corresponding `config.yaml` file will be rejected per the schema.

Those two fields should be whitelisted to allow the following config.yaml to be validated against this schema without issues.


```yaml
# defaults list
defaults:
  - hydra/job_logging: disabled

# hydra node
hydra:
  job:
    name: test

# and some user config
name: foo
age: 12
```

items.title: Add support for specifying an additional config dir in the command line
items.body:
This is useful for standalone apps that want to come with their own configs but also allow users to add additional configs that can be used with the composition.
```
├── my_app.py
├── conf
│   ├── config.yaml
│   └── dataset
│       └── imagenet.yaml
└── user-dir
    └── dataset
        └── cifar10.yaml
```

config.yaml:
```
defaults:
  - dataset: ???
```

my_app.py:
```python
@hydra.main(config_path="conf", config_name="config")
def my_app(cfg: DictConfig) -> None:
    print(cfg.pretty())

if __name__ == "__main__":
    my_app()
```
In the above example, normal run results in:
```
$ python my_app.py 
You must specify 'dataset', e.g, dataset=<OPTION>
Available options:
        imagenet
```

The app sees only the built in config dir `conf`.
The user can specify an additional config dir via the command line:

```
$ python my_app.py --config-dir user-dir
You must specify 'dataset', e.g, dataset=<OPTION>
Available options:
        cifar10
        imagenet
```
Now the app sees both configs.
The user now normally override the dataset:
```
$ python my_app.py --config-dir user-dir/ dataset=cifar10
dataset:
  name: cifar10
```

items.title: command line is incorrectly removing whitespace in primitives
items.body:
```commandline
$ python foo.py "+x=a b c"
```
results in:
```yaml
x: abc
```

because the grammar is ignoring whitespace outside of quoted strings and there is a concatenation phase for primitives.

items.title: [Doc] Ax plugin should use underscores
items.body:
I was playing around with Ax plugin: works like a charm 💯 

The docs are slightly misleading though:

```
banana.x:
 type: range
 bounds: [-5, 5]

banana.y:
 type: range
 bounds: [-5, 10.1]
```

Will not work and should be `banana_x` as in the [example](https://github.com/facebookresearch/hydra/blob/master/plugins/hydra_ax_sweeper/example/conf/config.yaml). It would also be good to document the use of having to escape underscores `\\_`. I had to dive in the code to understand how to properly use the plugin from a config file.

# 🐛 Bug
## Description
Not sure whether this is expected behavior. If it is, it should be documented somewhere. If you register a custom OmegaConf resolver at module scope, they won't be propagated to the launcher processes. Thus when you try to access a config node which uses a custom resolver, you get an exception.

- [x] I checked on the latest version of Hydra
- [x] I created a minimal repro

# foo.py
import hydra
from omegaconf import OmegaConf


def my_custom_resolver():
    return "foo"


OmegaConf.register_resolver("my_custom_resolver", my_custom_resolver)


@hydra.main(config_name="foo")
def main(cfg):
    assert cfg.x == "foo"


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

# foo.yaml
x: ${my_custom_resolver:}
```

items.title: [Bug] autocompletion is not working if PATH environment has `.` in the list
items.body:
# 🐛 Bug
## Description
Basically when you install it for that terminal it is not working.
So I did comparison with my MacOS installation (all the same versions of hydra and stuff) and got that the difference in behavior comes from `command` tool.
Here is how it reacts on working side (on my mac):
```shell
$ command -v python simple.py
/path/to/bin/python
```
And how it reacts in CentOS:
```shell
$ command -v python simple.py
/path/to/bin/python
./simple.py
```
## Expected Behavior
I was able to fix it by replacing this in the autocompletion installation script:
```bash
 if ! [ -x "$(command -v $helper)" ]; then
        false
 fi
```
to this one:
```bash
cmd=($(command -v $helper))
if ! [ -x "${cmd[0]}" ]; then
        false
fi
```

## System information
- **Hydra Version** :  1.0.0rc3
- **Python version** : 3.8.3
- **Virtual environment type and version** : conda, 4.8.3
- **Operating system** : CentOS7
- **Bash Version** : 4.2.46(2)

items.title: [Submitit]: Setting environment variables from launcher
items.body:
# 🚀 Feature Request

It would be nice to be able to set environment variables from Submitit launcher.

Right now it's possible (but a bit hacky) in submitit (https://github.com/facebookincubator/submitit/issues/10) but I think it should also be possible from the launcher. The simplest way would be to add a parameter `setup` for slurm launcher.

Usecase: I'm training pytorch models using a distributed backend and need to set the flag "NCCL_DEBUG=INFO" to see actual errors in the code rather than NCCL errors.

@jrapin

items.title: [Bug] root logger has FileHandler after using `hydra_task_runner`
items.body:
# 🐛 Bug
Once `hydra_task_runner` is called from a unit test, a FileHandler seems to be registered to the root logger of `logging`. When a logger tries to log something from another test, it fails because of the staled FileHandler.

I could successfully make the tests pass by manually removing the FileHandler, i.e., adding `getLogger().handlers.pop()` at the end of `test_1()`. But it doesn't seem to be an elegant solution. Probably is it possible to remove additional handlers in `TaskTestFunction.__exit__()` or somewhere?

## To reproduce
```
from logging import getLogger


def test_1(hydra_restore_singletons, hydra_task_runner):
    with hydra_task_runner(
        calling_file="test_hydra.py",
        calling_module=None,
        config_path=".",
        config_name="config.yaml",
    ):
        logger = getLogger(__name__)
        logger.info('test_1')


def test_2():
    logger = getLogger(__name__)
    logger.info('test_2')
```

Then run pytest.

** Stack trace/error message **

items.title: Relative variable interpolation
items.body:
# 🚀 Feature Request

(This might actually be a feature request for OmegaConf, but perhaps easier to describe here.) 

It would be great to support relative variable interpolations like so:

In dataset/ucf/train.yaml
```
# @package _group_

target: torchvision.datasets.UCF101
params:
  fold: 1
  metadata_file: /path/to/${.fold}.pth
```

#### Why not just use something like `${dataset.params.fold}` instead?
That would work in simple cases. However, when overriding this package into multiple config groups, eg:

in config.yaml
```
defaults:
  - dataset@dataset_1: ucf/train
  - dataset@dataset_2: ucf/val
```

`${dataset.params.fold}` won't exist, and will have to choose between `${dataset_1.params.fold}` or `${dataset_2.params.fold}` etc., each of which might independently override the `fold` parameter, making it tricky to decide which one to use for interpolation.

Not sure how easy or feasible something like this is, but thought might be worth asking

items.title: [Feature Request]
items.body:
# 🚀 Feature Request

<!-- A clear and concise description of the feature you are requesting -->
Don't capture exception when running hydra application in debug mode in pycharm.

## Motivation

When developing algorithm, I often use debug mode in Pycharm, which stops the program right in the place where the exception is thrown. This makes debugging super easy and pleasing.

Right now, when encounters error, hydra kill the program using `sys.exit(1)`. It will be better if instead of exit the program, hydra re-throws the exception so the debugger can catch it. If the exception isn't catched, then the program exit as normal.

## Pitch

**Describe the solution you'd like**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you want to happen. -->

It will be better if instead of exit the program, hydra re-throws the exception so the debugger can catch it. If the exception isn't catched, then the program exit as normal.

items.title: [Feature Request] Add support for some features from gin-config
items.body:
# 🚀 Feature Request

Support some features in [gin-config](https://github.com/google/gin-config)
- Passing functions, classes, and instances ("configurable references") as a config node for `instantiate`
- Configuring the same function in different ways ("scopes")

This way, hydra will be super powerful. 

## Motivation

For example when instantiate an optimizer, net parameters to be optimized are passed as an argument.
Hope to specify which parameters to be passed in the config file. 

## Pitch

Take gin-config code for example
- python code
```python
@gin.configurable
class DNN(nn.Module):
    def __init__(num_layers):
         ...

@gin.configurable
def get_parameter(net):
    return net.parameters()

gin.external_configurable(torch.optim.Adam)

@gin.configurable
def trainer(optim1, optim2):
    ...
```

- gin config file
```
dnn1/DNN.num_layers = 5
dnn2/DNN.num_layers = 10 

dnn1/get_parameter.net = @dnn1/DNN
dnn2/get_parameter.net = @dnn2/DNN

torch.optim.Adam.lr = 0.01
dnn1/torch.optim.Adam.params = @dnn1/get_parameter()
dnn2/torch.optim.Adam.params = @dnn2/get_parameter()

trainer.optim1 = @dnn1/torch.optim.Adam
trainer.optim2 = @dnn2/torch.optim.Adam
```


## Additional context
More detailed description about gin-config
https://github.com/google/gin-config/blob/master/docs/index.md

# 🐛 Bug

## To reproduce
**Minimal Code/Config snippet to reproduce**
Folder structure:
`code/example_code.py`
```
import pytorch_lightning.metrics.functional as plm

class sample_fucntion:

items.title: Commandline interpolation by indexing lists
items.body:
I recently switch to using the master branch due to #748 .
It looks like the commandline syntax has changed and it doesn't seem possible to do interpolation by indexing lists (or I couldn't figure it out).

For example, for a config containing:
```
listconf: [2,3]
newlistconf: [3,4]
```

In v0.11, I could do `python main.py newlistconf.0=\${listconf.0}`
But now, on master, this throws the following error:
```
Error parsing override 'newlistconf.0=${listconf.0}' : extraneous input '.0' expecting '='
```

Even `python main.py newlistconf=\${listconf.0}`, throws the following error:
```
Error parsing override 'newlistconf=${listconf.0}' : mismatched input '{' expecting <EOF>
```

Can you let me know if there's a new syntax for doing this? I couldn't figure it out from [https://github.com/facebookresearch/hydra/blob/master/hydra/grammar/Override.g4](url)

Thanks!

items.title: [Docs] In documentation, add a section on how to setup the website locally
[Feature Request] Detect missing arguments in multirun before actually launching the job(s)
items.body:
# 🚀 Feature Request

With `--multirun`, fully validate the config (in particular for potentially missing arguments) of all jobs before launching them.

For instance, with the following script:

```
from dataclasses import dataclass

import hydra
from hydra.core.config_store import ConfigStore

from omegaconf import MISSING


@dataclass
class MySQLConfig:
    host: str = MISSING
    port: int = 3306


cs = ConfigStore.instance()
# Registering the Config class with the name 'config'.
cs.store(name="config", node=MySQLConfig)


@hydra.main(config_name="config")
def my_app(cfg: MySQLConfig) -> None:
    print(f"Host: {cfg.host}, port: {cfg.port}")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    my_app()
```

==> the following command line would fail before submitting anything to SLURM (while currently it doesn't): `python my_app.py hydra/launcher=submitit_slurm -m`

## Motivation

When launching with `--multirun` on a cluster for instance, it can take a long time (several hours) before these jobs actually start. If there is a missing argument it's best to know about it immediately rather than wait for the job to start.

## Pitch

**Describe the solution you'd like**

I'd like Hydra to run a validation pass on the config before running each job with `--multirun`, and fail immediately if any job has a missing argument (or any other config issues, for that matter -- I discovered this issue with missing arguments but I don't know if some other checks might be delayed as well).

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Wait until the job is launched :)

**Are you willing to open a pull request?** (See [CONTRIBUTING](../CONTRIBUTING.md))

No

items.title: [Bug] With a List[int] config option (structured config), a single integer is still parsed as an integer
items.body:
# 🐛 Bug

Let's say you have a structured config with a single `List[int]` option named `fudge`:

```
@dataclass
class Config(DictConfig):
    fudge: List[int] = field(default_factory=lambda: [])
```

I would expect an error when running `python hydra_basic.py fudge=1`, however it runs fine and `fudge` becomes the integer `1` instead of being a list.

## To reproduce

```
from dataclasses import dataclass, field
from typing import List

import hydra
from hydra.core.config_store import ConfigStore
from omegaconf import DictConfig


@dataclass
class Config(DictConfig):
    fudge: List[int] = field(default_factory=lambda: [])


@hydra.main(config_name="config")
def my_app(cfg: DictConfig) -> None:
    print(cfg.fudge, type(cfg.fudge))


if __name__ == "__main__":
    cs = ConfigStore.instance()
    cs.store(name="config", node=Config)
    my_app()
```

Run `python app.py fudge=1`

1 <class 'int'>

items.title: Clean up instantiate
items.body:
instantiate for classes only
call for callables.
### instantiate
```
foo:
  type: ...
```
```python
object = instantiate(cfg.foo)
```

### call
```
foo:
  callable: ...
```
```python
ret = call(cfg.foo)
```

for backward compatibility, instantiate and call should still support both inputs but issue deprecation warning if the wrong input is specified.

items.title: Switch internal resource loading to importlib-resources
items.body:
importlb-resources is the next gen Python resource loader and will become the standard one in Python 3.9 (importlib.resources).
It has several advantages over pkg_resources, such as better performance and more consistent and well designed API.

pkg_resources has some side effects related to pytest plugins that are also a reason to avoid it.

Hydra 1.0 is switching to importlib-resources based ConfigSource for loading resources from packages, and the current pkg_resources implementation will be replaced.
for simplicity there will be no phase when both approaches are supported at the same time.
For the most part, this should be transparent to users.

Hydra will be more strict about requiring an `__init__.py` in config modules moving forward when the included config is loaded from the module and not the file system and in general it is not recommended to always include an `__init__.py` file at the top config modules or directories.

NOTE:
People using Hydra from the master will have to reinstall hydra-core to run the tests and may have to uninstall hydra-pytest-plugin (if they have it installed).

[Feature Request]
items.body:
# 🚀 Feature Request

Accessing the application help and making use of it from the application code

## Motivation

**Allow the application to access the application help and make use of (ex: print/show it to the user) when incorrect usage is identified.**

## Pitch

Identify wrong usage patterns and showing the correct usage to the user is a critical aspect in any application. Hydra may be enhanced in future to specify mandatory configuration parameters and constraints specifying correct usage patterns. But, it is also a good idea to allow the application access the application help text and make use of it when it encounters wrong usage scenarios.

If I understand correctly, Hydra doesn't provide any mechanism to the application to access the help text/template provided in the hydra configuration.  Please correct me if I am wrong. My exposure to hydra is just about a day old. The methods with access to the application seemed to be in the internal methods of Hydra. It would be of great help if Hydra provides a way to expose the help text to the application some way or other.

Please correct me, if such a mechanism already exists.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Provide a method such as hydra.app_help() or hydra.utils.app_help()

items.title: [Bug] KeyError: '_dh'
items.body:
# 🐛 Bug

`KeyError: '_dh'` when importing a module that uses `hydra.experimental.initialize`

## To reproduce

** Minimal Code/Config snippet to reproduce **


main.ipynb Jupyter notebook:

```
import hydra.experimental
hydra.experimental.initialize(config_path="conf")
cfg=hydra.experimental.compose(config_name="config.yaml")

import module
```

module.py:
```
import hydra.experimental
hydra.experimental.initialize(config_path="conf")
cfg=hydra.experimental.compose(config_name="config.yaml")
```

** Stack trace/error message **


```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
KeyError                                  Traceback (most recent call last)

----> 1 import module

~/dev/htest/module.py in <module>()
      1 import hydra.experimental
----> 2 hydra.experimental.initialize(config_path="conf")
      3 cfg=hydra.experimental.compose(config_name="config.yaml")

/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/hydra/experimental/compose.py in initialize(config_path, strict, caller_stack_depth)
     23     """

items.title: [Feature Request] Document usage without functions (top-level)
items.body:
# 🚀 Feature Request

Document how to use Hydra without functions

## Motivation

In Jupyter notebooks, you may want access to Hydra configs when you are not within a function. This is because it's easier to test Jupyter scripts where the code is top-level. However, you still want access to Hydra configs.

Please document how to use Hydra when you are not within a function, for example in a Jupyter notebook.

items.title: Save .hydra/*.yaml before task execution
items.body:
# 🐛 Bug

Saving the configurations is a really cool idea that helps me check what I actually did. I noticed the save timing is delayed after task execution in the `1.0.0rc1`. I have encountered some scenarios that I think it would be better if the configs are saved earlier.

For example,

1. Tasks may exit accidentally due to bugs. Knowing detailed configurations would be helpful.
2. For time-consuming tasks like ML training which may last for several days, it would be helpful to be able to check the config.yaml. This helps me a lot when I have multiple tasks running but I can't remember the real difference. I do `diff config.yaml`.
3. Some tasks don't need to be finished. The full training may be designed to run 100 epochs but it also happens it's aborted/killed in the middle.

## To reproduce

Default behavior in `1.0.0rc1`.

** Minimal Code/Config snippet to reproduce **
NA

NA

NA

RC releases on conda-forge?
items.body:
# 🚀 Feature Request

Really appreciate the publishing of stable releases on conda-forge! I was wondering if it would be possible to add an RC branch for the upcoming 1.0 release on the relevant feedstocks?

## Motivation

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Installing the current RC versions of Hydra and OmegaConf break conda's dependency resolution algorithm. This necessitates uninstalling and reinstalling both before and after executing any package management commands.

## Pitch

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Some form of (presumably automated) process for updating the `rc` branches of both OmegaConf and Hydra feedstocks so as to expose conda-compatible pre-releases.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Perhaps pulling RC's off of PyPI? I've read that conda-forge does this already for some packages, but not sure if it's applicable for pre-releases.

## Additional context
https://github.com/conda-forge/cfep/blob/master/cfep-05.md
